# Camus

[![Build
Status](https://travis-ci.com/camuschat/camus.svg?branch=master)](https://travis-ci.com/camuschat/camus)
[![docs](https://img.shields.io/readthedocs/camus/latest)](https://docs.camus.chat)
[![PyPI](https://img.shields.io/pypi/v/camus-chat?color=blue)](https://pypi.org/project/camus-chat)
[![Docker
Hub](https://img.shields.io/docker/pulls/camuschat/camus)](https://hub.docker.com/r/camuschat/camus)
[![License](https://img.shields.io/github/license/camuschat/camus?color=green)](https://github.com/camuschat/camus/blob/master/LICENSE)

Camus is a group video chat app that uses
[WebRTC](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebRTC_API)
for direct peer-to-peer communication. Users can create and join rooms,
stream audio and video with a microphone and webcam, share their screen,
and send text messages. You can try a demo at <https://camus.chat>, or
run your own server using
[Snap](https://docs.camus.chat/en/latest/installation.html#snap),
[pip](https://docs.camus.chat/en/latest/installation.html#pip),
[Docker](https://docs.camus.chat/en/latest/installation.html#docker), or
[Heroku](https://docs.camus.chat/en/latest/deployment.html#heroku).

## Features

  - Create public or private rooms, optionally with a password and guest
    limit
  - Stream audio & video
  - Share your desktop
  - Send text messages
  - Control video feeds -- set your camera resolution, toggle fullscreen
    or picture-in-picture, disable incoming video
  - Configure custom STUN and TURN servers
  - Responsive user interface that works on large or small screens

![image](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/camuschat/camus/master/screenshots/0.2.0.png)

## Installation

### Snap

Make sure you have [snapd](https://snapcraft.io/docs/installing-snapd)
installed. Install [Camus](https://snapcraft.io/camus):

    $ sudo snap install camus

Once installed, Camus runs automatically as a Snap service. See the Snap
[service management](https://snapcraft.io/docs/service-management)
documentation for details on starting and stopping services.

Go to `localhost:5000` in your browser. For local testing, you can visit
the same room in multiple tabs and each tab will act as a separate
client.

### Pip

Camus requires
[Python 3.7](https://docs.python.org/3.7/whatsnew/3.7.html) or higher
since it makes use of [Quart](https://gitlab.com/pgjones/quart) and
async syntax. As usual, it's best to use a [virtual
environment](https://docs.python.org/3/tutorial/venv.html).

Install Camus:

    $ pip install camus-chat

Run Camus:

    $ camus

Go to `localhost:5000` in your browser. For local testing, you can visit
the same room in multiple tabs and each tab will act as a separate
client.

### Docker

You can find a [pre-built Docker
image](https://hub.docker.com/r/camuschat/camus) on Docker Hub. Use the
following command to pull the image and run a container:

    $ docker pull camuschat/camus
    $ docker run -d -p 5000:5000 camuschat/camus

Go to `localhost:5000` in your browser. For local testing, you can visit
the same room in multiple tabs and each tab will act as a separate
client.

### Heroku

[![Deploy to
Heroku](https://www.herokucdn.com/deploy/button.svg)](https://heroku.com/deploy?template=https://github.com/camuschat/camus)

Simply click the button above or see the [deployment
documentation](https://docs.camus.chat/en/latest/deployment.html) for
detailed instructions.
